narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The theory of randomized algorithms and tools for their analysis.
Learned about various ways to apply randomization to algorithms. The PSETs were challenging but interesting.
Knowledge of several different probability bounds, like chernoff and azuma hoeffding
How to apply various concentration bounds to analyze randomized algorithms

Learned several fundamental techniques + paradigms in randomized algorithm design + related fields, including
-Hashing/PRG's
-Martingales/Stopping Times
-Markov Chains
-Sampling
-Quantum Computing
-Spectral Methods
I learned about randomized algorithms.
randomized algorithm ability
Theory of basic concentration bounds, Markov chain, FPTAS, and others that are related to randomized algorithm
I learned about ways to come up with algorithm to compute approximate solutions to hard problems in a time efficient manner with randomization
Lots of concentration bounds and markov chain techniques
Reasoning about the probability of events, knowledge of concentration bounds, understanding of Markov chains
Probability theory and algorithm
basic knolwedge and skills on Randomized algorithms

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lectures are very, very hard to follow. Prof. Aspnes has no slides which makes it extremely difficult.
Great class!
The topics were generally interesting. I would have liked to have one or two coding assignments on top of the proofs that we completed.
The problem sets were interesting and required inspiration, and the curriculum material was written clearly. There could be more concrete examples and implementations given in lectures

Strengths: 
Content is extremely interesting, and Prof. Aspnes does make the class enjoyable. 
Psets. had interesting problems. 

Weaknesses:
Pacing of the lectures was sort of all over the place.
Great psets!

The course is designed to be easy to teach (for someone who knows the material very well), with it seems very little consideration for ease of learning. Lectures proceed at a rapid-fire pace, rushing through the content identically to how it is presented in the online notes and content is often disconnected by months from problem sets. For this reason, about 8 of the 60+ students enrolled in the course attended lecture after the first 2 weeks, and among those about 5 (including myself) were consistently paying attention rather than doing homework for another class. 

Lectures Need More Focus: work through 1-2 examples showing every step rather than 4-5 examples, 3 steps at a time. The instructor includes lots of historical background to the methods used in examples, unfortunately many of the algorithms and techniques used in the examples were "motivated" with "nobody actually uses this anymore" alongside some dates and authors. 

Content Needs More Reinforcement: 3 problem sets were issued throughout the semester to form the sum of grades for the course. With assignments covering months of material at a time, and no practice problems given for students to work through themselves on the material since it was introduced months ago, I could expect to open each problem set with only a vague idea of where to get started in relearning the material that was introduced, never used, and long-since forgotten.

This Course Needs a Real TA: The ULA that joined on for this course hardly ever showed up to their office hours, and had not prepped or been prepped for the assignments to any useful degree when they were present. 

Collaboration Needs More Structure: Collaboration is encouraged in problem sets, which is great if you had friends in the class going into it because the 4 other students that were paying attention in class were already working together. 

Instructor Office Hours Need a Larger Space: OH with the instructor were a great resource for understanding material if a problem set had not yet been released, but were packed full (in office) whenever a pset was out. Asking basic questions in a public-format style, in a room full of other students many of which were enrolled in more advanced probability courses alongside this one and seemed to have a better grasp of the material, was discouraging and intimidating.
Very clear, good lecture note
Difficult to follow lectures after Week 5
Due to there only being three HW assignments, we were not tested on all the material, so I would not say I learned all of the content equally well.
The pdf notes are useful. The ULA of this course was not helpful during office hours. He asked me a term that is straight from a textbook. Professor office hours are helpful
Strengths: Phenomenal lecture notes

Prof. Aspnes has extensive theory knowledge and writes detailed notes for each class he teaches, including this one! However, I had difficulty keeping up with the pace of the lectures at times, especially when I tried to take notes while following along. My level of engagement with the class was also quite low, considering the only assignments we had were three problem sets.

Lectures could be more organized - there were instances while going through proofs in class where steps were confusing, or we would find a mistake that required backtracking. I was happy about the amount of homework assigned, but the questions were difficult and could have been a better learning experience with more hints/guidance.
I think it is well designed

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It is a very, very low workload class. But if you want to actually learn something, the material is very difficult and lectures are impossible to follow.
Yes if they want to learn theory.
Straightforward CS elective where you learn some cool concepts. Pretty good class.
Yes but not as a practical course, more theory and algorithmic and probability analysis
Yes, although this class is very much "what you put in, you get out" since there were only 3 psets + no final.
Awesome course if interested in randomized algorithms. Aspnes knows his stuff.
If you or one of your friends considering this class with you have a commanding grasp on advanced probability concepts, sure!
Yes
No, it is quite difficult to follow along lectures as Aspnes goes very fast.
If they are interested in Algorithm designs, this is an interesting course for them
Yeah, go for it!

I recommend this class if you like algorithms and preferably have some mathematical maturity or exposure to probability. While it is low workload (this semester we only had 3 psets), it is not necessarily a true gut since it is NOT EASY. The second half of the content is analogous to that of an advanced graduate algorithms class and some of the problems are very involved and can be very difficult to come up with a solution to. This is magnified by the fact that office hours with Prof Aspnes and the ULA are largely useless and you are on your own along with any friends in the class, so befriend people or take it with your friends! That makes the class more manageable along with a lot of topics in class  not being covered on psets so you can just not attend class or read the lecture notes half the time. The grading is 100% from problem sets and grading is very prompt (few day turnaround) if Aspnes grades himself. An additional note is that taking this class alongside Stochastic Processes is a great pair since the Martingales and Markov Processes parts overlap but both classes explain it through different lenses so it provides a deeper understanding of the material. For a list of topics covered, see the course typed notes.

It depends. If you're interested in theory and are a diligent self-learner, I would recommend this class. Otherwise, probably not. Your entire grade is based on three psets (there may be a few more assignments if there are TAs), so there's not a whole lot of structure. I would strongly recommend keeping up with the class notes Prof. Aspnes does a good job indicating which sections of the notes correspond to each lecture, and if you really want to understand the material you should read the notes carefully.
Yes, if learning probability theory is their interest
